newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.

text.p: CONCERNS OVER POTENTIAL OF LIVING WAGE CLAIM
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry is warning that business growth would be devistated if the ACTU's full "Living Wave" claim is granted.
This follows the Reserve Bank's examination, in its lastest bulletin, of the implications of the full claim being granted by the Industrial Relations Commission.
The Bank says the direct effect of the sought after 8-and-three-quarters percent pay rise would be to lift aggregate wage growth well over the danger level of five-per cent.
But the Bank also says that if that happens, it would come with higher interest rates to hold back the rate of inflation.
KIDNAPPED NURSE HOME FOR CHRISTMAS
Australian nurse Maree Worthington, who was released earlier this month after being kidnapped by rebels in Sudan, will be home in Sydney for Christmas.

Ms Worthington arrived in Melbourne last night after spending some time at the Geneva Headquarters of the Red Cross. Secretary General of the Australian Red Cross, Jim Carlton says she looks healthy, and is in great spirits.
Ms Worthington had been working in Sudan for five months, when she was detained by a breakaway faction of the Sudanese People Liberation Army and held captive for five weeks.
DROUGHT EXCEPTIONAL CIRCUMSTANCES SUPPORT REVOKED
Federal Primary Industries Minister, John Anderson, has announced drought exceptional circumstances support for parts of New South Wales and Queensland will end on December the 31st this year.
Mr Anderson says the climatic outlook has improved, with winter and early spring rains providing drought-breaking conditions for winter crop and pasture production.
In Queensland, he's revoked drought exceptional circumstances support in the shires of Diamantina and Barcoo.
In New South Wales, they've been revoked in parts of the the rural land protection board areas of Hay, Hillston, Brewarrina, Balranald and Nyngan.
Mr Anderson says exceptional circumstances support has been ended for the whole shires of Dubbo, Bathurst, Mudgee, Molong and Merriwa.
PARER DEFENDS FOREST MINING DECISION
Federal Resources Minister, Warwick Parer, says the Forest industry has an incredible record of forest rehabilitation.
Senator Parer has defended Cabinet's decision to allow mining in some forest areas, saying he wants areas of high mineral potential excluded from new forest reserves.
Mining will also be allowed in informal reserves, which are classified as less environmentally significant than dedicated reserves.
The States will be allowed to permit mining in dedicated reserves if the Commonwealth agrees.
While the plan's been criticised by conservation groups and the Opposition, Senator Parer has told ABC radio, the mining industry has a good record of working in forests.
MILITARY HAIRCUTS NON-DISCRIMINATORY

The Federal Sex Discrimination Commissioner says the dismissal of a soldier's claim that defence force haircuts for men are discriminatory, shows that different treatment isn't necessarily detrimental.

At the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, RAAF Corporal Carl Trindorfer argued that regulations requiring men to have a short military style haircut denies them the freedom available to women.
In dismissing the complaint the Commission rejected the notion the Corporal received less favourable treatment, and said the uniformity of appearance is important for RAAF morale.
CASH MAKES COMEBACK
Pat Cash makes a low-key comeback to tournament Tennis in Melbourne today.
The 1987 Wimbledon champion is taking part in the Aussie Assault - a round-robin event for Australian players to give them practise on Melbourne Park's Rebound Ace courts.
Six men and four women are taking part, with a purse of $2,500 for each winner.
Cash will play James Sekulov in his first tournament appearance since withdrawing midway through a match at the Beijing Open, citing mental fatigue as the problem.
CRITICISM OVER SPORTS FUNDING
There's criticism from athletics officials after the announcement the AFL will recieve more than a million dollars extra Federal funding.
Athletics was one of the losers recently when the Australian Sports Commission announced its funding levels leading up to the Sydney Olympics.
And now the AFL has been promised more than a million dollars to establish its Player Academy and Hall of Fame.
Athletics Australia chief, Neil King says it's a curious situation when our top track and field hopes must compete as virtual amateurs.
ACB ON PAKISTAN'S TOUR SCHEDULE
Australian Cricket Board chairman Dennis Rogers says any problem the Pakistan cricket captain has with his team's Australian tour schedule should be taken up with Pakistan's Cricket Board.
Wasim Akram says the schedule is very frustrating, because the one-day tournament could have been competed in three or four weeks.
Akram says instead, his team has a fortnight between international matches.
Dennis Rogers says the tour schedule was negotiated by the cricket boards of both countries, and those conditions would have been agreed to by Pakistan.
